channel.title: Android rootkit
channel.description:
http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20006596-83.html
Security researchers plan to demonstrate a rootkit running on an Android-based smartphone that could give an intruder full access to all the functions of the device
Apperantly it can be triggered by a phone call, :0

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I thought everything for iPhone was written in Objective-C and could only be compiled using X-code running under OSX? Whether that is just a front-end for gcc I don’t know though.

right, xcodes compiler is gcc

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:18, topic:352438”]heh, im not sure iptables can count given that its just the usermode counterpart to something in the kernel… its “part of the kernel” in a project sense, even though the binary runs in usermode

the others ill give you, though. i have no idea if modifications to darwin for the iphone get patched in upstream either, but i suspect they probably dont. dont forget iphone also uses gnu stuff too (gcc being the biggest example i guess)[/quote]

I thought everything for iPhone was written in Objective-C and could only be compiled using X-code running under OSX? Whether that is just a front-end for gcc I don’t know though.

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

heh, im not sure iptables can count given that its just the usermode counterpart to something in the kernel… its “part of the kernel” in a project sense, even though the binary runs in usermode

the others ill give you, though. i have no idea if modifications to darwin for the iphone get patched in upstream either, but i suspect they probably dont. dont forget iphone also uses gnu stuff too (gcc being the biggest example i guess)

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

Would the same not apply to the iphone os, given that Darwin is to it what GNU/Linux is to Android?

Except no iOS source code modifications (which are very many) must be released, where as the GNU GPL requires the entire Android kernel to be released with modifications and tools to compile it. Also Android uses many other tried and true open source applications as well, a few I can think of right now are iptables, wpasupplicant, and busybox. Probably also whatever it uses to play audio etc etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:

Would the same not apply to the iphone os, given that Darwin is to it what GNU/Linux is to Android?

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:14, topic:352438”]Why can’t the attacker use the exploits you use when you root your phone to load the rootkit?

EDIT: Ah, you do them from a PC, they’re not like the iphone exploits. Still, it would be naive to assume android dosen’t have remote holes.[/quote]

But probably much less holes, since much of the software is in current use and has been for years in countless other devices, and also since the source code is public. (Although it is hurt slightly since many applications aren’t open-source)

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Why can’t the attacker use the exploits you use when you root your phone to load the rootkit?

EDIT: Ah, you do them from a PC, they’re not like the iphone exploits. Still, it would be naive to assume android dosen’t have remote holes.

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

uh, why would a kernel mode rootkit, once installed, need to go through su?

My bad, I didn’t read the article so I didn’t see the ‘kernel-level’ comment.

Either way, the user has to manually root the phone, and allow the rootkit program to use su at least once. To remove it, the user would just have to install the update.zip again (re-install the ROM).

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

uh, why would a kernel mode rootkit, once installed, need to go through su?

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:9, topic:352438”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=448788.msg3293948#msg3293948 date=1280811910]

  1. The user would have to ‘root’ the phone, most don’t.
  2. The user would have to run the program, and allow it to use root permissions, probably no one would.
    [/quote]

So you package it alongside a useful app and have the app root the phone…[/quote]

Apps can’t root phones. You have to download a signed update zip to your sd card, reboot into recovery, and apply the update manually.

[quote=“Nueb35, post:10, topic:352438”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=448788.msg3293948#msg3293948 date=1280811910]
Those ‘security researchers’ must be complete idiots. Newsflash, a virus is just a program, obviously you can write a program for the phone to run as root and do whatever-the-hell you want it to do, just like any other device that runs programs in the entire world, including ‘jailbroken’ Apple products. For it to work on Android though, two things have to happen:

  1. The user would have to ‘root’ the phone, most don’t.
  2. The user would have to run the program, and allow it to use root permissions, probably no one would.

[/quote]

if the parent of a program is root don’t the permissions get passed down as well? so if the trigger (for example, the call) is root, wont the program it runs also be root? and it sounds like it just runs a shell and allows the person to use the shell from a remote location, so no program is actually installed (until the hacker installs it from the remote machine using the shell)[/quote]

The way ‘root’ works on android is via a ‘su’ binary, which is managed by a ‘super user permissions’ program. No app can get root privileges unless you specifically allow it to (and it will ask every time, unless you check a box that says always allow). So, IF a phone is already rooted by the user, and IF a ‘rootkit’ is published with a useful app, and IF a user allows that app to use root permissions, then it can be ran. Simply removing it from the superuser allow list and restarting your phone should stop it permanently though.

Again though, anything that can run programs can run malicious programs.

Read full topic

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:352438”]Those ‘security researchers’ must be complete idiots. Newsflash, a virus is just a program, obviously you can write a program for the phone to run as root and do whatever-the-hell you want it to do, just like any other device that runs programs in the entire world, including ‘jailbroken’ Apple products. For it to work on Android though, two things have to happen:

  1. The user would have to ‘root’ the phone, most don’t.
  2. The user would have to run the program, and allow it to use root permissions, probably no one would.[/quote]

if the parent of a program is root don’t the permissions get passed down as well? so if the trigger (for example, the call) is root, wont the program it runs also be root? and it sounds like it just runs a shell and allows the person to use the shell from a remote location, so no program is actually installed (until the hacker installs it from the remote machine using the shell)

Read full topic

2. The user would have to run the program, and allow it to use root permissions, probably no one would.[/quote]

item.title: Android rootkit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Those ‘security researchers’ must be complete idiots. Newsflash, a virus is just a program, obviously you can write a program for the phone to run as root and do whatever-the-hell you want it to do, just like any other device that runs programs in the entire world, including ‘jailbroken’ Apple products. For it to work on Android though, two things have to happen:

  1. The user would have to ‘root’ the phone, most don’t.
  2. The user would have to run the program, and allow it to use root permissions, probably no one would.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

CNET – 2 Jun 10

Researchers to demo rootkit on Android phone

Defcon demo to show rootkit running on an Android-based smartphone that could give an intruder full access to all the functions of the device.

Security researchers plan to demonstrate a rootkit running on an Android-based smartphone that could give an intruder full access to all the functions of the device

Apperantly it can be triggered by a phone call, :0
